unnormalised: Flipkart's Big Billion Days sale just wrapped up, and the numbers are pretty staggering! Sources say they moved over ₹40,000 crore worth of goods this year. That's a lot of sarees, smartphones, and kitchen appliances!
normalised: Flipkart's Big Billion Days sale just wrapped up, and the numbers are pretty staggering! Sources say they moved over rupee forty thousand crore worth of goods this year. That's a lot of sarees, smartphones, and kitchen appliances!

unnormalised: Amazon's Great Indian Festival sale, still ongoing, is also reporting huge figures. Early estimates put their sales at around ₹35,000 cr already. Apparently, electronics and fashion are flying off the virtual shelves.
normalised: Amazon's Great Indian Festival sale, still ongoing, is also reporting huge figures. Early estimates put their sales at around rupee thirty five thousand crore already. Apparently, electronics and fashion are flying off the virtual shelves.

unnormalised: Analysts are pointing to the increased use of UPI and other digital payment methods. Almost 80% of transactions were cashless, which is a significant jump from last year. And with EMI options becoming more widespread, even big-ticket items are becoming more accessible.
normalised: Analysts are pointing to the increased use of U-P-I and other digital payment methods. Almost eighty percent of transactions were cashless, which is a significant jump from last year. And with E-M-I options becoming more widespread, even big-ticket items are becoming more accessible.

unnormalised: A lot of people are crediting the sheer volume of discounts. We’re talking upto 70% off on some brands, and then the extra 10% instant discount on select credit cards. No wonder everyone's going crazy!
normalised: A lot of people are crediting the sheer volume of discounts. We’re talking up to seventy percent off on some brands, and then the extra ten percent instant discount on select credit cards. No wonder everyone's going crazy!

unnormalised: But it's not all sunshine and roses. There were reports of delivery delays and some confusion with order cancellations. Many customers were complaining online that their orders marked "delivered" never actually arrived! There's also the whole debate around whether these sales are *really* discounts, or just clever marketing.

unnormalised: Smaller businesses have mixed feelings. While these mega-sales boost overall e-commerce activity, they also make it harder for smaller players to compete. They just can't offer the same level of discounts.
normalised: Smaller businesses have mixed feelings. While these mega-sales boost overall e-commerce activity, they also make it harder for smaller players to compete. They just can't offer the same level of discounts.

unnormalised: Despite some hiccups, the e-commerce giants are calling the festive season a major success. They are looking forward to more sales events like this, with even crazier deals.
